Preinstallation> Preinstallation # Update system clock> Update system clock # $ timedatectl set-ntp true
Partition the disks> Partition the disks # Use the TUI tool to partition your disk in the GPT format:
$ cfdisk
For an installation, you need at least:
a 100Mb boot partition a root partition a swap partition (optional) To list your partitions, use:
$ lsblk
Format the partitions> Format the partitions # Format the root partition into the ext4 format:
$ mkfs.ext4 /dev/root_partition
Format the boot partition:
$ mkfs.fat -F 32 /dev/boot_partition
Make the swap partition:
$ mkswap /dev/swap_partition
Mount the partitions> Mount the partitions # Mount the root partition onto /mnt:
$ mount /dev/root_partition /mnt
Mount the boot partition, and create the EFI directory:
$ mount --mkdir /dev/boot_partition /mnt/boot/efi
Start the swap volume:
$ swapon /dev/swap_partition
Ensure the partitions are mounted with:
$ lsblk
Installation> Installation # Install essential packages> Install essential packages # Install essential packages using the pacstrap command:
$ pacstrap /mnt base linux linux-firmware networkmanager nano base-devel sof-firmware grub efibootmgr
base-devel contains packages necessary for building packages, required for the AUR networkmanager is necessary for internet connection post install nano is a text editor, replace as necessary sof-firmware is required for some soundcards grub is a bootloader, replace as required efibootmgr allows grub to work on EFI systems os-prober allows grub to recognize other operating systems Genfstab> Genfstab # Generate fstab file:
$ genfstab -U /mnt >> /mnt/etc/fstab
cat /mnt/etc/fstab to check for errors
Pro-tip. Use tmux to split your terminal and type out this command while waiting for your pacstrap to finish
Arch-chroot> Arch-chroot # Change root to /mnt:
$ arch-chroot /mnt
Time zone> Time zone # Set the time zone:
$ ln -sf /usr/share/zoneinfo/Region/City /etc/localtime
Generate /etc/adjtime:
$ hwclock --systohc
Locale> Locale # Edit /etc/locale.gen and uncomment your preferred localization ( for example, en_US.UTF-8 UTF-8):
$ nano /etc/locale.gen
Create locale.conf, and add your localization, substitute as necessary:
$ echo "LANG=en_US.UTF-8" >> /etc/locale.conf
Set your hostname> Set your hostname # Create the hostname file, and add a name to the file:
$ nano /etc/hostname
Root user> Root user # Create a password for the root user:
$ passwd
Install the bootloader> Install the bootloader # Install the grub bootloader using:
$ grub-install /dev/disk_with_partitions
Create a grub config file using:
$ grub-mkconfig -o /boot/grub/grub.cfg
At this point, feel free to type exit and then reboot… hopefully your installation has been successful.
